description: From Middle English clubbe, from Old Norse klubba, klumba (“cudgel”), from Proto-Germanic *klumpô (“clip, clasp; clump, lump; log, block”), from Proto-Indo-European *glemb- (“log, block”), from *gel- (“to ball up, conglomerate, amass”). Cognate with English clump, cloud, Latin globus, glomus; and perhaps related to Middle Low German kolve (“bulb”), German Kolben (“butt, bulb, club”).

definitionGroups.group: An association of members joining together for some common purpose, especially sports or recreation.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The fees associated with belonging to such a club.
examples: He can have no right to the benefits of Society, who will not pay his Club towards the Support of it.

definitionGroups.group: A heavy object, often a kind of stick, intended for use as a bludgeoning weapon or a plaything.

entries.meaning: An implement to hit the ball in certain ball games, such as golf.
A joint charge of expense, or any person's share of it; a contribution to a common fund.
examples: first we went and dined at a French house , but paid 10s for our part of the club

entries.meaning: An establishment that provides staged entertainment, often with food and drink, such as a nightclub.
examples: She was sitting in a jazz club, sipping wine and listening to a bass player's solo.

definitionGroups.group: A black clover shape (♣), one of the four symbols used to mark the suits of playing cards.

entries.meaning: A playing card marked with such a symbol.
examples: I've got only one club in my hand.

entries.meaning: (humorous) Any set of people with a shared characteristic.
examples: You also hate Night Court?  Join the club.
Michael stood you up?  Welcome to the club.
Crab cake sandwiches, tuna melts, chicken clubs, salmon cakes, and prime-rib sandwiches are usually on the menu.

entries.meaning: The slice of bread in the middle of a club sandwich.

verbs.description: club (third-person singular simple present clubs, present participle clubbing, simple past and past participle clubbed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To join together to form a group.
examples: Till grosser atoms, tumbling in the stream / Of fancy, madly met, and clubb'd into a dream.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To combine into a club-shaped mass.
examples: a medical condition with clubbing of the fingers and toes
When I was younger, I used to go clubbing almost every night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To pay an equal or proportionate share of a common charge or expense.
examples: The owl, the raven, and the bat / Clubb'd for a feather to his hat.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To raise, or defray, by a proportional assessment.
(nautical) To drift in a current with an anchor out.
(military) To throw, or allow to fall, into confusion.
(transitive) To unite, or contribute, for the accomplishment of a common end.
(transitive, military) To turn the breech of (a musket) uppermost, so as to use it as a club.
